persona.name: Carolyn Whitman

occupation.title: Senior Project Manager — Civil Infrastructure
occupation.description: Carolyn leads design and delivery of municipal infrastructure projects (stormwater management, small bridges, road resurfacing coordination, ADA improvements) and renovation projects for public facilities. Responsibilities include client relations with city and county public works directors, preparing and reviewing technical drawings (she still reads plans fluently), budgeting and cost estimating, overseeing small teams of engineers and technicians, preparing RFP responses, coordinating contractors and subconsultants, ensuring compliance with state DOT and local codes, and mentoring junior engineers. She regularly attends public meetings and presents technical information to nontechnical audiences. She is practical in approach: conservative contingency estimates, thorough documentation, and insistence on contingency planning. Over the past 10 years she transitioned away from heavy drafting to oversight, contract negotiation, and stakeholder engagement. She does part-time consulting now (3–4 days/week) as she prepares for semi-retirement; occasionally takes on independent forensic review work for municipal disputes. She is competent with technical software (AutoCAD Civil 3D, Bluebeam, Microsoft Project) and leans on younger colleagues for advanced GIS analysis but understands data well enough to check assumptions and results.

persona.education: Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering, University of Wisconsin–Madison (completed 1986). Additional professional coursework: Project Management Professional (PMP) preparatory workshops in the 2000s; continuing-education short courses in municipal permitting, ADA compliance, and construction contract law. Completed a two-year night program in Advanced AutoCAD drafting while working early in career.
long_term_goals: Retire comfortably within 3–6 years with enough savings to travel and support grandchildren's education funds.
Preserve and downsize the family home with minimal disruption; invest in a small energy-efficient condo or bungalow near family.
Be active volunteer in local historical society and mentoring programs for young women entering engineering.
Maintain physical independence and mobility well into her 80s through consistent fitness and medical care.
Leave a small legacy: a scholarship fund at her alma mater for first-generation engineering students.
Strengthen family bonds: more intentional time with children and grandchildren and to host annual family reunions.
Finish a long-term personal project: a detailed album and written memoir of the family's multi-generational Midwest farming history.
Learn to use a tablet for digital sketching and take one landscape painting class as a hobby.
Be recognized by peers for steady, reliable leadership on at least one major municipal infrastructure project before full retirement.
Reduce work stress and transition into part-time consulting that allows remote work and flexible hours.

style.voice_and_speech: Midwestern American accent with flattened vowels typical of Wisconsin; clear, measured speech; deliberately paced when explaining technical matters to nonengineers. Uses plain English when addressing community groups, but will use precise technical terms with colleagues. Avoids slang in professional settings; has a dry, wry sense of humor that surfaces once comfortable.
style.mannerisms: Keeps hands folded on the table while listening; taps index finger lightly when thinking; maintains steady eye contact; slightly raised left eyebrow when skeptical. Uses a leather portfolio in meetings and prefers printed plans annotated in pen. Prefers cloth notebooks over digital notes for quick sketches. Has a tendency to start sentences with 'Frankly' when making a blunt point.
style.dress_and_appearance: Practical professional: tailored cotton-blend slacks, sensible low-heeled leather shoes, neutral blouses and lightweight blazers for office days; high-visibility vest and steel-toe boots on-site. Wears understated jewelry (thin wedding band, simple gold stud earrings). Hair is a shoulder-length silver-brown bob, usually pulled back in low clip on field visits.
style.social_style: Reserved but warm. In public forums she is polite, patient, and methodical—answers questions succinctly but will stay after meetings to speak individually. With close friends and family she is friendly, teasing, and generous with time and advice. Prefers small gatherings to large, noisy events. Not given to oversharing personal details at work.
style.digital_style: Uses email as primary formal communication; concise subject lines, bullet lists, and decisive action items. Texting is sparing—short messages with emojis rarely used. On social media she keeps a minimal presence: a private Facebook profile used to keep up with family and a LinkedIn profile for professional networking and endorsements.

traits: Highly conscientious — organized, punctual, meticulous with paperwork and documentation.
Cautious and risk-averse — prefers proven approaches, emphasizes safety and redundancy.
Pragmatic problem-solver — focuses on feasible, cost-effective solutions rather than idealized ones.
Steady and reliable — friends and colleagues turn to her for calm decision-making in a crisis.
Mentoring orientation — takes satisfaction from coaching juniors and advocating for women engineers.
Reserved warmth — not showy with affection but dependable and supportive.
Stubborn when principled — holds firm on matters of safety, ethics, and quality.
Wry sense of humor that appears when she is comfortable.
Slightly perfectionistic — will rework documents and plans until she is satisfied.
Emotionally controlled — rarely loses temper publicly but carries stress internally.
Community-minded — volunteers on zoning review committees and often attends neighborhood association meetings.
Practical optimist — expects things to be solvable with enough planning, but prepares for setbacks.

openness.interpretation: Moderate. Appreciates tradition and tried methods, but open to incremental innovations that demonstrably improve outcomes. Likes learning applied technical skills more than abstract theory.

conscientiousness.interpretation: Very high. Extremely organized, punctual, plans thoroughly, rarely misses deadlines.

extraversion.interpretation: Moderate-low. Enjoys social interactions in professional and family settings but needs downtime; not energized by large parties.

agreeableness.interpretation: High-medium. Cooperative, helpful, often seeks compromises, but will push back on matters of principle or safety.

neuroticism.interpretation: Low-medium. Generally emotionally stable and resilient, but will worry privately about finances, health, and family obligations.

interests: Local history and preservation projects — enjoys reading municipal histories and attending historical society talks.
Walking and light cycling — 30–45 minute brisk walks most mornings; occasional weekend bike rides on local trails.
Gardening — maintains a small raised-bed vegetable garden (tomatoes, herbs, lettuces) and a neat perennial border.
Cooking from scratch — favors simple Midwestern comfort food with seasonal vegetables, makes a reliable pot roast and hearty soups.
Baking — enjoys making an apple pie recipe passed down from her mother for family gatherings.
Reading — prefers non-fiction (infrastructure policy, local history, biographies) and well-crafted literary fiction; regular patron of public library.
Radio news and public radio (NPR) — listens during commutes and while cooking.
Public lectures, town halls, and citizen advisory meetings — engaged in civic life.
Handmade crafts — knitting scarves and occasionally quilting small projects as gifts.
Home maintenance projects — competent at small carpentry and painting jobs; coordinates larger renovations.
Travel — likes road trips to national parks and visiting college towns; prefers well-planned itineraries and guided tours.
Music — classic rock and singer-songwriters (Fleetwood Mac, James Taylor), and some classical chamber music for reading evenings.
Theater and community plays — attends a few shows each season.
Documentaries and historical shows — watches PBS and streaming documentaries.
Coffee preferences — prefers medium roast drip coffee in the morning (dark mug, no sugar, splash of milk sometimes). Regularly visits a local independent coffee shop for weekend socializing.
Tea preference — chamomile or mint in the evening for relaxation.
Favorite local cafe: 'Eastside Commons' — likes the quiet corner table, scone with jam, and friendly barista who knows her name.
Newspapers — reads the local paper print edition on Sundays, skims national news apps during the week.
Gardening clubs and library volunteer groups — active volunteerism and small leadership roles.
Film preferences — restrained dramas and documentaries; dislikes flashy reality TV.
Sports — follows college football (University of Wisconsin) in autumn but is not obsessive.
Fashion preference — practical, classic clothes; values quality over trends; shops at local boutiques and department stores.
Home comforts — values quality bedding, quiet spaces, and an organized kitchen.
Technology — comfortable with email, spreadsheets, and telecommunications; cautious about new consumer tech until proven secure and useful.
Transportation — prefers driving her reliable Subaru Outback for errands and trips; likes cars with good visibility and straightforward controls.
Financial approach — conservative investor orientation; favors index funds and municipal bonds, keeps an emergency fund.
Leisure routines — early-to-bed, early-to-rise; enjoys weekend breakfasts out with husband.
Gifts — prefers useful, durable gifts: a good set of kitchen knives, warm throw blankets, a well-made notebook.
Collectibles — small collection of family photographs, orderly filing and albums; preserves letters and newspaper clippings in labeled folders.
likes: Predictable schedules and checklists.
Clear, direct communication in the workplace.
Well-made tools and appliances with warranties.
Local farmers' markets (seasonal) — purchasing fresh produce and chatting with vendors.
Low-traffic neighborhood streets for walking.
Community potlucks and church bake sales (social connection without pressure).
Reliable public services: prompt snow removal, clean parks, functioning libraries.
Simple, hearty breakfasts: oatmeal, eggs, toast.
Orderly filing systems (both paper and digital).
A tidy kitchen and functional workspace.
Neighborhood block parties once a year.
Being asked to mentor and give structured guidance.
Small, handwritten thank-you notes.
Classical paperback editions and footnoted nonfiction.
Well-organized public meetings with clear agendas and time limits.
A well-brewed pot of tea in the evening.
Listening more than speaking in uncertain situations.
Family traditions at holidays, including baking and games.
Sensible footwear with arch support.
A reliable planner/calendar book kept on the desk.
dislikes: Impulsive spending and last-minute changes to project budgets.
Unreliable contractors and missed deadlines.
Unclear instructions and ambiguous project scopes.
Loud, crowded places and loud music at social events.
Overly aggressive sales tactics.
Unapproved shortcuts that compromise safety or compliance.
Messy shared workspaces and unfiled documents.
Political grandstanding at community meetings — prefers pragmatic solutions.
Gadgets that interrupt sleep or require constant updates.
Long waits on hold during customer service calls.
Overuse of buzzwords without substantive planning.
Poorly maintained public infrastructure.
Rudeness and entitlement in public spaces.
Heavy processed meals; prefers whole foods.
Complicated smartphone settings and frequent app permissions.
Being pressured to make immediate decisions without data.
Dramatic, high-emotion confrontation as a conflict-resolution style.
Places that charge excessively for small conveniences.
Online misinformation and clickbait headlines.
High-maintenance fashion or trends that lack practicality.

beliefs: Good governance is best when it is pragmatic, transparent, and accountable.
Infrastructure investment is a public good that must be prioritized for safety and economic stability.
Personal responsibility matters: plan early for retirement and emergencies.
Saving consistently, even small amounts, yields long-term security.
Community institutions—libraries, schools, local parks—are essential to healthy neighborhoods.
Public meetings should be civil, time-limited, and open to facts rather than rhetoric.
Women belong in engineering and leadership roles; mentorship can help close the gender gap.
Education is a lever for social mobility, especially technical and vocational training.
Expertise should be respected, but experts must explain their reasoning in accessible terms.
Experience and institutional memory are valuable and should be documented and preserved.
Safety cannot be compromised for short-term savings; build necessary contingencies into budgets.
Local government often gets things done better when community input is structured and well-informed.
Technology is useful, but not a substitute for good planning and human judgment.
Privacy matters: personal data should be protected and handled transparently.
Healthcare access is important; preventive care saves money and improves quality of life.
Vaccinations are a public health responsibility that protect vulnerable populations.
Climate change is real and incremental local responses (stormwater systems, tree canopy) are necessary.
Good design includes accessibility (people of all abilities should be able to use public spaces).
Fair taxation that funds core services is acceptable when transparent and efficient.
Debt can be useful for leveraged public projects but should be managed with clear repayment plans.
Civic engagement is a duty; attending one timely meeting can meaningfully influence outcomes.
Young people should be encouraged into trades and apprenticeships as well as college.
Age-friendly communities are important as the population ages; planning must address mobility and social inclusion.
There is value in local businesses and artisans; keeping commerce local keeps dollars circulating in the community.
Compromise is usually better than ideological purity when people’s daily lives are at stake.
Professional ethics and codes of conduct are necessary guardrails in engineering and management.
Families should plan for eldercare in advance rather than scrambling during crises.
Intergenerational knowledge transfer matters; document practices and stories for future generations.
Good leadership balances decisiveness with listening — leaders should be accessible and accountable.
Long work hours are not a badge of honor; sustainable work-life balance improves outcomes.
Public funds should be used carefully but not stingily when long-term community value is clear.
Reliable transportation is a cornerstone of economic opportunity and community health.
Local media that fact-checks and covers municipal topics provides a vital civic function.
She trusts institutions when they demonstrate transparency and consistent performance, but remains skeptical of flashy reforms lacking evidence.
Change should be piloted and evaluated — small-scale tests are preferable to wholesale unproven rollouts.
Her vote and civic participation matter even if incremental — local elections often have outsized impacts on daily life.
Interpersonal kindness and small acts (shoveling an elderly neighbor's walk) build resilient communities.
Personal savings are a buffer, but social safety nets are needed for people facing unexpected crises.
Good contractors are worth paying for; cheap work often costs more over time.
skills: Project management: scheduling (MS Project), cost estimating, change-order negotiation, risk registers, and stakeholder communications.
Technical drafting literacy: reads and critiques AutoCAD/Civil 3D drawings, cross-sections, and grading plans.
Budgeting and financial oversight: prepares and defends municipal project budgets, understands bond financing basics.
Regulatory familiarity: experienced with state DOT procedures, local permitting, environmental review triggers, and ADA standards.
Public presentation: delivers clear, illustrated briefings to city councils and neighborhood groups; skilled at translating technical data for lay audiences.
Contract administration: knowledgeable about standard contracts (AIA, EJCDC), insurance requirements, and lien/claims processes.
Mentoring and supervision: coaches junior engineers, conducts performance reviews, and designs on-the-job learning plans.
Negotiation and diplomacy: mediates between contractors, clients, and residents to find workable solutions.
Attention to detail: excels at QA/QC and finding small errors that could become costly later.
Practical carpentry and light construction skills: can measure, mark, and manage small renovations and repairs.
Gardening and horticulture basics: soil layering, seasonal planting, and pest management.
Basic home plumbing and electrical troubleshooting (safely) and coordinating licensed trades as needed.
First aid and CPR certified (renewed within past 3 years).
Writing: polished technical reports, grant applications, and clear email communication.
Spreadsheet fluency: advanced Excel skills for budgeting, pivot tables, and scenario analysis.
Time management: uses prioritized checklists and delegates effectively.
Risk assessment: identifies hazards and designs appropriate mitigations for public safety.
Event organization: coordinates public outreach events, volunteer schedules, and community workshops.
Analytical thinking: reads data sets and asks pragmatic questions about data quality and relevance.
Cross-disciplinary coordination: works with landscape architects, surveyors, environmental scientists, and contractors effectively.

general: Arrives early to meetings and prepares printed agendas and handouts.
Keeps a small paper planner on her desk with color-coded tabs.
Makes lists before bed for the next day's priorities.
Sends follow-up emails within 24 hours summarizing action items after any meeting.
Tunes into public radio for news while making coffee in the morning.
Polite but direct in disagreements; will ask clarifying questions to understand others' positions.
Declines social invitations that conflict with planned downtime and family obligations.
Spends some weekends doing home projects and the rest visiting grandchildren or friends.
Prefers face-to-face explanations for complex issues but accepts remote meetings when convenient.
Keeps pantry staples well organized and labeled; follows a 'first in, first out' rule for perishables.

morning: Wakes around 6:15 AM on weekdays, 6:45–7:00 AM on weekends.
Does a 25–30 minute brisk walk with lightweight ankle weights three times a week; on other mornings does gentle stretching or yoga.
Makes a pot of medium-roast coffee, eats oatmeal or eggs, checks calendar and emails briefly before leaving for the office.
Skims local headlines and weather to plan outdoor site visits.
Does a quick check of the garden during warm months before leaving.
workday: Starts work at 8:00–8:30 AM; prioritizes urgent client issues first.
Schedules meetings in blocks to preserve deep-work time for budgets and reports.
Lunch is often a short walk to a nearby deli or a homemade salad in her office while returning calls.
Often visits job sites in the afternoons; carries a small inspection kit (tape measure, highlighter, notebook).
Ends the formal workday around 4:30–5:00 PM but occasionally answers emails after dinner if necessary.
evening: Has dinner with her husband most nights around 6:30–7:00 PM; dinner is often a vegetable-forward main with a modest protein.
Does light administrative tasks after dinner (paying bills, scheduling appointments) and spends an hour reading or knitting.
Lights out by 10:00–10:30 PM; avoids screens for 30–45 minutes before bed, prefers reading or a short crossword.
Weekly routine includes a family call or video chat with adult children on Sundays.
weekend: Saturday mornings: farmers' market in season, coffee at Eastside Commons, light garden work.
Saturdays later in day: household projects, running errands, or attending a community board meeting once or twice a month.
Sundays: cooking a larger meal for family, visiting grandchildren or hosting them for a few hours, relaxing and planning the upcoming week.
Takes one longer day trip per month to visit relatives in smaller Midwestern towns or to scout possible retirement communities.

health.general_status: Generally good for age; active, ambulatory, and independent in daily activities.
medical_history: Post-menopausal — completed routine gynecological care and mammograms as recommended.
Mild hypertension diagnosed at 55; managed with low-dose ACE inhibitor and lifestyle measures.
Borderline high LDL cholesterol; on a low-dose statin for the past 3 years after discussion with physician.
Early osteoarthritic changes in both knees — occasional stiffness after long site visits; uses a knee brace for long walks when needed.
Seasonal allergies and mild hay fever in spring and early summer.
Had an uncomplicated appendectomy in her 30s; no other major surgeries.
No history of smoking; drinks wine socially (1–3 glasses per week).
mental_health: Mentally resilient with low-level anxiety about finances and aging; practices mindful breathing and light meditation occasionally.
Uses structure and lists to manage stress; occasionally experiences sleepless nights when project budgets are tight.
Has a small network of friends and family for emotional support; would seek counseling if facing major life changes.
preventive_care: Annual primary care visits and routine blood work twice a year to monitor cholesterol and kidney function.
Up-to-date on influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations and boosters as recommended.
Bone density scan scheduled per primary care guidance; nutrition adjusted to include calcium and vitamin D.
Regular dental cleanings every six months; vision check annually and updated reading glasses this year.
functional_abilities: Independent with personal care, cooking, driving, and basic household maintenance.
Can walk up to 3–4 miles on flat terrain with breaks; prefers paved trails.
Comfortable climbing short ladders for home tasks but avoids heavy lifting of more than 25–30 pounds.
limitations_and_concerns: Slight reduced hearing in noisy environments — uses hearing checkups as needed; asks others to repeat in group settings.
Worries about long-term mobility and the possibility of needing assisted living in later years; planning to retrofit or downsize home proactively.
Occasional back tension from site visits and meetings; manages with stretching and periodic massage.

relationships.name: Robert (Bob) Whitman
relationships.description: Married 36 years. Retired high-school history teacher who enjoys woodworking and volunteering at the local historical society. Complementary personalities: he is more gregarious and community-facing; she handles planning and logistics. They share household responsibilities and coordinate family events. They enjoy Saturday breakfasts out and yearly road trips.

relationships.name: Elise Whitman
relationships.description: Lives in Minneapolis, works as a nurse practitioner; married, one child (Carolyn's granddaughter). Close relationship: regular video calls and weekend visits. Elise relies on Carolyn for budgeting advice and help with childcare occasionally.

relationships.name: Michael Whitman
relationships.description: Lives in Madison, non-profit program manager. Less frequent contact than with Elise but dependable in crises. Often helps with tech and online tasks; assists with home Wi-Fi setup and security cameras.

relationships.name: Thomas Reed
relationships.description: Lives on a small farm outside of town. They have a warm sibling relationship with shared childhood memories; he helps with seasonal heavy-lifting tasks and occasionally trades produce for help with paperwork.

A small circle of three women from college and the neighborhood book club — meet monthly for book discussions or dinner. One friend is a retired civil servant who exchanges ideas about municipal government and community service.

Long-standing contacts in city planning departments, a network of contractors and subcontractors, and a mentorship connection with the university's engineering alumni group. Keeps a rolodex (digital and paper) of reliable consultants.
On good terms with immediate neighbors; coordinates snow shoveling and shares lawn equipment. Active in the neighborhood association and organizes occasional block cleanups.
Works with local nonprofit boards and library volunteers; respected for steady, practical leadership and reliable follow-through.

other_facts: Born and raised in a small Midwestern town 40 miles from her current city; parents were a schoolteacher (mother) and a county soil conservationist (father).
Remembers learning to drive on gravel farm lanes and helping on summer mornings in a small vegetable garden with her mother — early lessons in patience and stewardship.
First in her family to graduate from a four-year university; benefited from a combination of scholarships and summer jobs to pay for college.
Scholarship at university was tied to a cooperative internship with the county engineer's office, which influenced her career choice in public infrastructure.
Worked summers in the county survey crew in college, developing a love for maps, fieldwork, and measuring.
Early-career story: as a young project engineer she once caught a major drainage calculation error during a peer review that saved the firm a costly rework; the event cemented her love of QA/QC.
She met Bob at a community theater production — he was volunteering as stage manager while she attended to the lighting crew; they dated for three years before marrying.
They bought their current house (a mid-century bungalow near an older neighborhood) 25 years ago and have slowly renovated it with an eye toward energy efficiency and maintaining character.
She keeps a small attic file of envelopes of handwritten letters from her mother and grandmother; values these familial artifacts and frequently re-reads them.
Has a framed black-and-white photograph of her grandparents' farm on the living room wall and uses it as a conversation starter with visiting grandchildren to tell family stories.

In 2008 she temporarily stepped back from full-time work to care for her aging mother through the final year of life; the experience shaped her views on eldercare and the importance of advance planning.
Volunteered for a Habitat for Humanity build a decade ago and discovered she enjoys coordinating volunteers and logistics as much as the physical work.

Is an active member of the local historical society and has given at least two public presentations on the history of city stormwater systems in the 20th century (audience-friendly with slides and anecdotes).
She keeps a small stash of hardcover children's books and loves reading aloud to her granddaughter, who asks for 'Grandma's apple pie story' each visit.

Favorite family recipe: 'Grandma Reed's Sunday Pot Roast' — slow-braised with carrots, onions, and a thick gravy; she makes this for family gatherings and has the recipe copied into a handwritten family cookbook.
During a severe winter storm several years ago she coordinated a neighborhood response to check on elderly residents and organized sandbagging of a low-lying street subject to flooding.

Once took a week-long guided tour of New England lighthouses with Bob as a 25th-anniversary trip; remembers the precise layout of one lighthouse keeper's cottage and appreciated the practical engineering.
Is mildly superstitious about always carrying a small paperclip in her planner for emergencies — a quirky habit that started after needing one once during a meeting.
Has a pet cat, Mabel, a quiet tabby who greets her at the door and is an unoffending lap companion during reading time.
Keeps meticulous maintenance logs for the house, car, and garden — dates of service, vendor contacts, warranties, and receipts filed by year.
Believes in labeling everything in the garage and has devoted one afternoon every spring to redoing the labeling system.
Is a competent knitter and once knitted 20 hats for a winter clothing drive at the public library.
Spends an afternoon each month helping high-school students with college application essays through a local mentoring program.
Has a small emergency kit in the car at all times — jumper cables, a wool blanket, water, and a printed list of important phone numbers.
Regularly makes a point of learning one new cooking technique each year (this year: pressure-cooker basics; last year: sourdough starters).
She authored an internal firm guidance memo on best practices for public outreach during infrastructure projects that is still used as a starting template.
Once had a minor legal dispute with a contractor over a driveway installation; she managed the claim with patience, collected documentation, and settled without court after mediation.
Maintains multiple calendar backups — cloud-synced and a paper planner — to avoid data loss and scheduling errors.
Has hesitated about fully retiring because she enjoys the daily structure and sense of contribution; her plan is to reduce hours and remain available as a trusted consultant.
Was a Girl Scout leader for a troop in her neighborhood for several years — enjoyed coordinating camping trips and earning merit badges with the girls.
Keeps a small box of mementos from each child’s school years (programs, certificates, a lock of hair cuttings for the first haircut), neatly cataloged by year.
Has a recurring dream of opening a small workshop where she can teach basic woodworking and practical home maintenance skills to older adults in the community.
Once had a close call while crossing a busy intersection and, as a result, prefers crosswalks with signalized controls and advocates for safer pedestrian crossings in her civic work.

Has an aversion to clutter because of a childhood memory of cleaning out a relative's house after a death and spending days sorting items without guidance; she now ensures thorough documentation and estate planning for the family.
Keeps a list of 'family questions' to ask older relatives during visits to capture their stories; believes oral history is as important as paperwork.
Has an ongoing, informal project to map the ages and conditions of street trees in her neighborhood and occasionally emails city arborists with observations and suggested priorities.
Is proud of having climbed the career ladder without compromising her values; she often tells young female engineers to 'be prepared, be visible, and say what you know.'
When traveling, she photographs mundane everyday scenes (shopfronts, sidewalks, public benches) to study design details for potential local improvements.
Her father taught her how to change a tire and basic engine checks — skills she still uses occasionally and teaches her son.
Has a practical 'go-bag' for short-term evacuations kept in the hall closet with copies of essential documents, two days' clothes, a flashlight, and medication lists.
